description.plain:
Lowkey is a Hip-Hop artist and political campaigner. He has worked with Immortal Technique, Wretch 32, Akala, Dead Prez and Outlawz. He is part of the supergroup Mongrel alongside members of the Arctic Monkeys, Babyshambles, and Reverend And The Makers. The band released their album Better than Heavy in tandem with the Independent newspaper in 2009.
 
His critically acclaimed music has received millions of streams on Spotify, sold over 25k albums digitally, and garnered over 45 million YouTube views. His 2011 independently released album Soundtrack to the Struggle charted #6 in the UK RnB chart, #9 in the UK Indie chart, #14 in the UK Download Chart, and #57 in the UK Albums chart. He was included in MTV Base Best of the Best UK MCs two years in a row. Charting at #10 in 2010 and #7 in 2011.
 
His most recent album Soundtrack to the Struggle 2 features Noam Chomsky, Frankie Boyle, and Ken Loach, and has been streamed millions of times. His forthcoming album promises to break further ground for independent political music.

Erik Prince Blackwater – it was terrorism

Everyday UK – that is terrorism, every day

Every day, every day, every day, every day, every day, every day

You think that we don't know know but we do...16Embed

description.plain:
This clever and moving tune is controversial but provoking. It was released as a single in December 2009.

Lowkey is a Muslim of Iraqi descent.

Interesting fact is that Lowkey was detained and interrogated no less than two times by Israeli officials upon arrival at Ben Gurion Intl Airport in Israel.

I hope you're somewhere listening to this
I wish I knew why you did what you did
Cause I still haven't really come to terms with the truth
There must have been something you were determined to do
The lessons you taught me, I can't forget
But there's so many unanswered questions
Now everything seems meaningless
You lived fast and died young
But my brother you were a genius
How could you ever believe that you'll survive
I don't care what they say, that shit is suicide
I won't lie, there was much distance between you and I
I should've told you not to do it, don't be stupid
You've got looks, got brains and your future's bright
Now you're gone I feel like I'm gon' lose my mind
I never thought you'd get yourself organised
I wish we saw the signs, the shock left us all traumatised
These are awful times, and I need more than rhymes
Cause this was more than a tragedy
You can't just cheat the forces of gravity
You left me here to hold a brave face supporting the family
[Verse 2: Lowkey]
In a way you were dying to live
It's fucked up man, I'm crying while I'm writing this shit
Water from my eyes is stopping me from lighting my spliff
Why didn't you realise that your life is a gift
Mum and Dad don't understand why they've outlived their son
Every single CD, Mix Tape and Album to come
Is dedicated to no other than my blood brother
But I hate you, for the way you made my Mum suffer
Words can't explain, how a certain part of my heart hurts with the harshest pain
Last time we spoke, we said we weren't brothers and we aren't the same
I told myself you were too far past insane
How could we not take your death badly
I just asked mum and she said your name meant happy

[Verse 3: Lowkey
But my soul is too cold to laugh
My heart bleeds when I'm looking at your old school photograph
I wish that I could touch your beautiful flesh
I'm writing but we ain't even had the funeral yet
Now death is something, that I'm staying ever ready for
You had plenty more to give, you weren't even 24
I don't understand why you had to die
In a lot of rappers rhymes, death is glamorised
Not me, I'll always stay remembering you
I should've known this was something you'd eventually do
When you got shift, we should've known it was bad
The next day I was sitting here consoling my Dad
It's like a nightmare, it still doesn't seem real
You might also like[Verse 4: Lowkey]
But this is my life, not some fucking deep film
It's the strange feeling I felt in the late night
Witnesses said that you fell from a great height
Can't be my brother man, tell me it ain't right
Right now I'd rather blaze, we could face life
Shit what a waste, what a shame
I just gotta make sure your life wasn't lost in vain
This is my brother, not just a departed friend
So hard for my marj and them to start again
From now on our lives will never be the same
We holding on too tight for the memories to fade
24 years was hardly a life
On the day you passed, it's like a part of me died
I've been scarred many times but this pain is so much worse
And it's so much harder to describe
You will still be missed
I'm sorry we didn't support you, we thought we did
I wish I broke your leg so you couldn't jump
Now all I can do...is rep your fuckin name like I should've done
Cause it's only right
I'm still not sleeping, but now I'm seeing your ghost at night
We all wish we could've stopped you
I know I can't go back in time now, but I want to
It's like a tightened knot that I can't undo
Why did I have to lose you to realise I loved you
Be careful what you wish for, in case it comes true
Right now I'm confused, feeling so subdued
When they arrested you, they wanted to sanction you
The only thing we did wrong was going and getting you
Next morning you was up, not doing what you was meant to do
That wasn't the life that you were meant to have
That wasn't the way that it was meant to be
You were sick, not physically but mentally
I still ain't got a fraction of this shit off of my chest
All that goes through my mind is the constant regret
Why why why did you die for no reason
All of a sudden the weathers cold its so freezin
Have you ever head the saying, when it rains it pours
Don't ever try to tell me my pain is the same as yours
Cause it's not, and everything isn't what it seems
I'm pinching myself but I know that this is not a dream
Why did you have to do that, this isn't fair
Listen my brother, never think that I didn't care
There's no words to describe the way that this feels
Now I can clearly separate the fake from the real
Why did everyone else have to be bro
I still can't quiet believe that you're actually gone
Just 5 days, 5 days and it feels like the same day
Weed ain't helpin but I need it just to maintain
Cause the bleak reality is terrible
And last night mom was practically hysterical
People I thought would care, couldn't care less
I need a lot of support cause I'm feeling bare stressed
And everyone else seems immature
I'm being tested, thinking what is there left that I'm living for
I need to clear my thoughts, stop thinking and try n breathe
Just a week ago I was so innocent and naive
Now my insides are burning like hells flames
I've realised up until now I've never felt pain
It's so evident that everything I cared about before was so irrelevant
There's certain people that call when they see that this shit is hurtin
But I see them for what they are now cause I'm a different person

R.I.P
In fact fuck R.I.P
I want you to live through me
Live through me...
Live through me...
Live...through...me...5Embed

songs.full_title: Who Said I Can't Do Grime by Lowkey
songs.title: Who Said I Can’t Do Grime
songs.title_with_featured: Who Said I Can't Do Grime

description.plain: This song does not feature on an album, nor does it have a music video. Regardless, it represents how incredibly talented the British grime scene is; though this isn’t commercially successful, Lowkey consistently refers and disses individuals, making this an absolutely incredible track.

description.plain: The intro to this track is inspired from the 2007 John Pilger movie War on Democracy where Pilger gives the same speech. The movie is about the US government attempting to undermine the dictatorship in Venezuela, hence the mention in this and other Lowkey songs.

songs.full_title: Cradle of Civilisation by Lowkey (Ft. Mai Khalil)
songs.title: Cradle of Civilisation

description.plain: In this song, Lowkey talks about the troubles happening in Iraq. Throughout the song, he mentions how much he misses Iraq after his parents had left in the 70’s for England, and how he wishes for peace in the area, yet he knows it’s hard because of all of the divisions between the people.

songs.full_title: Obama Nation (Part 2) by Lowkey (Ft. Black The Ripper & M-1)
songs.title: Obama Nation (Part 2)
songs.title_with_featured: Obama Nation (Part 2) (Ft. Black The Ripper & M-1)

description.plain: “Obama Nation (Pt. 2)” is a song by British rapper Lowkey, featuring fellow British rapper Black the Ripper and M-1 from the political hip-hop duo Dead Prez. The song is a sequel to Lowkey’s “Obama Nation”. Both songs are centred around the same subject. Lowkey raps about how Obama isn’t benefiting the US as president and how he drops bombs on other nations. The song is track 22 of Lowkey’s second studio album, “Soundtrack to the Struggle”. The song is produced by Nutty P. The song was very popular on YouTube (where the official video was put up) – where it was ranked the no. 1 Most Discussed, Top Favourited and Top Rated for the day in the Music category.

songs.full_title: Too Much by Lowkey (Ft. Shadia Mansour)
songs.title: Too Much

description.plain:
Lowkey raps about the difference of materialistic happiness and real happiness, coming to the conclusion that money doesn’t make you happy.

The song features a sample of Lauryn Hill’s “Take Too Much” and the beat is heavily based on this sample.

In the video, ‘Key shows scenes from Havana, Cuba and a short text near the end attempts to highlight the injustice of the American blockade against Cuba and uses the Cuban people as an example for his point that happiness exists even where there is a lack of materialistic pleasure.

songs.full_title: The Return of Lowkey by Lowkey
songs.title: The Return of Lowkey

description.plain:
The “Return of Lowkey” is the third song from the album Soundtrack To The Struggle 2.

The song signifies Lowkey’s return to music after a hiatus from 2012 to 2016 as well as increasing the anticipation (at the time) of the album. His verses exemplify his claim of being one of the best in the industry with a sharp lyrical, rhyme-packed display.

The intro of the song features Duane Jones, Akala and Ghetts who provide additional evidence supporting this claim.

Akala appears again in the outro alongside Bruce Real and Charlie Sloth to further compound the point.

songs.full_title: Ghosts of Grenfell by Lowkey (Ft. Mai Khalil)
songs.title: Ghosts of Grenfell

description.plain:
“Ghosts of Grenfell” is a tribute song in response to the Grenfell Tower tragedy that occurred in London on June 14, 2017. Lowkey, who is known for his mixture of social commentary and political content in his songs, has been vocal about this incident in interviews since it has occurred. This song serves a purpose to raise awareness of the event and remind people of the unclear circumstances surrounding it and of the lives that were lost.

As the song ends, we hear the names of those still missing but are still not part of the official figures of those confirmed dead (as of 9 August 2017).

This is the part 2 song of “Long Live Palestine”

This clever and moving tune is controversial but provoking. It was released as a single in December 2009.

Lowkey is a Muslim of Iraqi descent.

Interesting fact is that Lowkey was detained and interrogated no less than two times by Israeli officials upon arrival at Ben Gurion Intl Airport in Israel.

description.plain: After a long 7 year wait, Lowkey returns to claim his throne in his Fire In The Booth Part 2. He kicks it off by reminding everyone how unique he is. How does he do that? He raps the alphabet backwards. After so he touches on more sensitive and political points.
